p: Few studies provided strong evidence of larval competition between Culex and Ae. j. japonicus mosquitoes; therefore, we assumed only a small reduction (5â€“10%) in Culex larvae carrying capacity from establishment of Ae. j. japonicus. We found that the future climatic projections completely overwhelmed the potential benefits of this strategy. In high-elevation forests, our simulations showed only trivial improvement in PGR for Amakihi and Iiwi for the moderate climatic projection (RCP4.5) and almost no improvement in PGR when climate was favorable for mosquitoes ( S6 Table). Not surprisingly, this strategy had no benefit at mid elevation, where the climate was more favorable for mosquito recruitment and disease transmission. An additional problem with the introduction of Ae. j. japonicus is that this species is a vector of West Nile Virus as well as several other encephalitis viruses [ 52], which could have a disastrous impact on native Hawaiian birds.
